abstracts.cdata!:
The Bombay Urban Transport Project for
            India successfully achieved its primary objectives to
            improve the efficiency, productivity, and capacity of the
            Bombay Electrical Supply and Transport Undertaking (BEST).
            The project accomplished this through augmentation of the
            bus fleet, improving maintenance, increasing average bus
            speeds through better traffic management, and selected
            traffic engineering works and signal systems. Achievement of
            secondary objectives related to organizational, fiscal, and
            management aspects of BEST was mixed. The report recommends
            regularization of the financial and institutional
            arrangements for bus fare revisions and funding bus
            transport operations.  Progress was made in traffic
            management in the Bombay Metropolitan Area, but much remains
            to be done to achieve the full benefits of traffic
            management. Institutional development of the Bombay
            Metropolitan Region Development Authority (BMRDA)
            strengthened its capacity for investment planning. One
            lesson is that a complex set of factors affects the success
            of efforts to improve regional investment programming,
            including project scope and size; institutional structure;
            the status and nature of investment and development planning
            at the State Government level; and the status and nature of
            policy changes sought by a Bank-funded project. The results
            of the technical assistance and training component were
            mixed. Due largely to institutional causes, technical
            assistance was relatively ineffectual in some cases.
